channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao, Telangana Leader
item.description: India Ink spoke with Mr. Rao about the long fight for statehood and the challenges ahead for India’s 29th state.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao
item.media:description: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao has worked tirelessly to achieve his dream of creating a separate state for the people of Telangana.

item.title: India Ink: Kolkata Rape Victims Find a Police Officer Who’s on Their Side
item.description: Damayanti Sen, who is leading the investigations of two high-profile rape cases, has developed a reputation for efficiency and sensitivity.
item.dc:creator: By ANURADHA SHARMA

item.title: Euro Zone Inflation Stays Low; Joblessness Remains High
item.description: Official data showed unemployment still snagged at 12 percent and inflation stuck at 0.8 percent as the weak European recovery stumbles on.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Armed Men Take Position at Two Airports in Crimea
item.description: As the possibility of a showdown between Ukraine’s fledgling government and the Kremlin appeared to grow, airports at Simferopol and Belbek were being patrolled by uniformed men.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and PATRICK REEVELL
item.media:description: An unidentified armed man patrolled in front of the airport in Simferopol, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Crackdown on Baby Trafficking Zeros In on Websites
item.description: The police have broken up four online businesses that matched prospective adoptive parents with children needing homes — in reality, baby traffickers, the police said. Some of the sites posed as public welfare interest groups, or disguised the babies as “gold jewelry.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman holds a candle behind a board displaying photos of missing children. The Chinese police said they rescued 382 babies in an operation that broke up four major Internet-based baby-trafficking rings.

item.title: Putin Pledges Aid to Ukraine but Leaves Steps Unclear
item.description: The Russian president’s statement makes no mention of military measures, but Ukraine’s interior minister claims that Russian forces have taken over two airports in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin led a security council meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Crash That Kills Schoolgirls Highlights Thai Road Dangers
item.description: A study found that Thailand has the world’s second-highest road fatality rate in the world.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
item.description: The Lunchbox,” by Ritesh Batra, puts Old Hollywood style in a Mumbai that has escaped the cyber world.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Parting Shot at U.S. Ambassador, Inspired by Mao
item.description: The state-run China News Service published a critique of Gary F. Locke’s tenure as the U.S. ambassador to China, calling him a banana for his “yellow skin and white heart.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gary F. Locke, the first Chinese-American ambassador to China, at his farewell news conference in Beijing.

item.title: U.S. Militant, Hidden, Spurs Drone Debate
item.description: The U.S. government is considering whether to again take the extraordinary step of authorizing the killing of an American citizen, now living in Pakistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Crimea’s Bloody Past Is a Key to Its Present
item.description: The unrest in this multiethnic region of Ukraine is just the latest in its long history at the center of territorial disputes.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The Crimean War ensnared Russia, the Ottoman Empire, France, Britain and Sardinia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Video Game Uses Japanese War Criminals as Targets
item.description: The game, unveiled by People’s Daily Online Weibo, a microblog affiliated with the newspaper of the ruling Chinese Communist Party, is titled Shoot the Devils.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The targets are the 14 convicted Class A war criminals honored at the Yasukuni Shrine in Japan.

item.title: State Department Report Details Suppression of Human Rights Abroad
item.description: The government’s annual human rights assessment notes abuses in Egypt, Iran, Russia and elsewhere.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Naming of Officials in Ukraine Reflects Homage to Power of the Street
item.description: The inclusion of popular protest figures in an interim government reflected an effort to pay tribute to the role of the street in dislodging a president from power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian protesters rode Thursday past a barricade in Kiev.

item.title: Credit Card Debt Threatens Turkey’s Economy
item.description: The boom in consumer credit has become a serious risk for Turkish lenders, Standard & Poor’s warned in a new report.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers on Istiklal Caddesi, a popular Istanbul promenade teeming with shops and restaurants.

item.title: Melilla Journal: Africans, Battered and Broke, Surge to Europe’s Door
item.description: Large groups of sub-Saharan immigrants have been charging the fences into a Spanish enclave in Morocco, raising alarms over their efforts and the officials’ response.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: African migrants camp out in the hills of Morocco near the Spanish enclave of Melilla.

item.title: Grab for Power in Crimea Raises Secession Threat
item.description: Crowds filled the streets of the Crimean capital chanting “Russia, Russia,” and legislators called for a vote to redefine relations with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: British Lawmakers Intensify Focus on Head Injuries
item.description: Spurred by the momentum the issue has gained in the United States, Parliament is examining a tightening of the rules governing the response to sports-related concussions.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: World Briefing: Suicide Bomber Attacks Cafe in the Somali Capital
item.description: A suicide bomber drove a car loaded with explosives into a Mogadishu cafe frequented by members of the security forces on Thursday, killing at least 10 people.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Several Bombings Leave Dozens Dead in Iraq
item.description: At least 38 people were killed and more than 50 were wounded Thursday in a series of bombings in Iraq, three of them in Shiite areas of Baghdad, Iraqi officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing: Political Party Ends Blockade of NATO Supply Route in Pakistan
item.description: The opposition politician Imran Khan announced Thursday that his political party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, which governs the northwestern Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, would end its three-month blockade of a NATO supply route.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing: Much Food Is Lost or Wasted, World Bank Report Says
item.description: The world loses or wastes 25 to 33 percent of the food it produces for consumption, losses that can mean the difference between an adequate diet and malnutrition in many countries, the World Bank said in a report released Thursday.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Palestinian Found Dead After Standoff With Israelis
item.description: The Palestinian Authority condemned the killing, as Amnesty International published a report accusing Israeli forces of using excessive force in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: North Korea Is Said to Launch Missiles Into Sea
item.description: The North was said to have launched four short-range missiles off its coast, and a South Korean missionary held there appeared at a government-arranged news conference in Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Kim Jong-uk, 50, a South Korean Baptist missionary, at a news conference in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Thursday.

item.title: Cervelli and Yankees Teammates Show Support for Protesters in Venezuela
item.description: Francisco Cervelli and about a dozen of his teammates were photographed with the Venezuelan flag and signs for peace.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID WALDSTEIN
